I rarely review things, but this game deserves it; Bioshock Infinite is quite possibly the best game I've ever played, and I say that as someone who has never picked up a Bioshock game before. I came into this knowing nothing about the series with no real expectations one way or the other, and I left completely immersed and emotionally drained after the credits of Burial At Sea Part II rolled.

Solid gameplay, wonderful score, insanely creative and addictive story and two very satisfying endings (the DLC is a must--the game had a good ending without it but the DLCs kick it up a notch or ten). I will probably have Vie en Rose stuck in my head for another month at least before I cave and replay this.

The highly acclaimed Bioshock Infinite takes place in the sky town of spingleton, where the bad man Cornstarch wants to take the lady-lamb young Queen Elizabeth from your fingertips. The interesting thing about The Queen is she cries a lot and makes lots of tears that make black-and-white things appear like in the olden days. This is used as a very unique mechanic in battles to overcome Cornstarch's, Slater's and Mr. Vox Populi's men. Additionally, the town of spingleton has many sky train tracks that Booker can latch on an take The Queen on a sightseeing journey whilst being shot at. The enemies also vary quite a significant amount, from the fireman who ironically throws fire and explodes to the handyman who has hands.The special powers in this game, also knows as nigors, are as diverse as the number 8 and offer a great variation of gameplay. For example:

In one instance you may step back and press the button for you nigor to fire birds at the enemies to finish them off, or perhaps you may choose a different route and stay back and press the button for your nigor to throw a fireball at the enemy, or maybe you might choose instead to stay back and press the button for your nigor to use the lightning on your enemy and give them a shock (get it?), or you might diverge and choose to stay back and use the nigor that throws a ball of energy at them or even choose to stay back and make horse sounds as they decide to float. The list goes on...

The story of Bioshock is even more depthy, as the man Cornstarch and the relationship between him and The Queen becomes more evident. Trigger warning: [spoiler][b]Spooky ghosts are in this game.[/b][/spoiler]
Good/10 Story

Sometimes when you are so looking forward to playing a game you end up with such high expectations that the actual game cannot possibly live up to them. I had high expectations here but I was not disappointed. The game manages to keep all the core ingredients that made Bioshock so much fun. It is a gloriously detailed world with a fantastic story filled with audio diaries to flesh things out further. The combat is a fun combination of guns and, for want of a better word, magic like before which can be upgraded throughout the game. All the same things could have been said about Bioshock 2 but that just felt like it was retreading the same ground; here it has taken those key ingredients but applied them to a sufficiently different environment to reawaken that wonder of exploring the world. The other major difference is that it has less of a horror feel and more of an action feel. Overall this is an excellent game, well worth spending your money on.

Awesome first-person experience, breathtaking story and astonishing graphics!

Recommended!

Bioshock Infinite, da ist sich Presse und Community einig, ist einer der besten Ego-Shooter für Einzelspieler. Das Spiel verspricht eine spannende Geschichte um das eigene Alterego Booker und dessen Sidekick Elizabeth. Dabei werden philosophische, theologische wie auch gesellschaftskritische Fragen aufgeworfen.

Fernab von Rassismus und der Frage nach dem Glauben, dreht sich letztlich alles um Elizabeth die mit ihren übermenschlich, geistigen Fertigkeiten Zeit und Raum brechen kann. Ein durchaus gelungenes spielerisches Element, was Bioshock Infinite durchaus von anderen Spielen abhebt. 

Auch die Welt Columbia, in der die Geschichte spielt, ist durch und durch stimmig. Die Stadt über den Wolken, das Steampunksetting. Soweit, so gut. 

Unterm Strich wird hier jedoch nicht wirklich viel neues Geboten. Die Shooterelemente, wie Waffengattungen, Perks etc. gab es alles schon und teilweise auch liebevoller gestaltet. Auch die anfangs witzigen Dialoge zwischen dem Sidekick Elizabeth und dem eigenen Alterego Booker nerven irgendwann bzw. plötzlich von geskripteten Ereignissen unterbrochen.

Auch die philosophische bzw. gesellschaftskritische Keule, mit denen das Spiel einen förmlich erschlagen möchte, tragen irgendwann nicht zu weiteren Spielmotivation bei. Auch das Setting um die fliegende Stadt Columbia wirkt aus der Ferne betrachtet lächerlich. Nehmen wir die Washington-Roboter-Gegner mit Amiflaggen auf dem Rücken. Sicherlich sollen diese den Patriotismus der Amerikaner persiflieren, jedoch ist die Art und Weise sehr plakativ. Oder vll nicht jedermanns Humor. 

Ich empfehle statt Infinite auf jeden Fall den Serienerstling, mit der Unterwasserstadt Rapture. Hier wird Kritik wesentlich besser verpackt, das Spiel wirkt weniger wie ein Comic und das Setting unter Wasser ist wesentlich stimmiger.

Würdet ihr also bitte den ersten Teil spielen?!

Bioshock Infinite is an amazing RPG-FPS game.
It is definately one of the best games of 2013.
The story is based around Booker Dewitt who has to find a girl named Elizabeth and bring her to a man in New York to remove his debts.
While playing, the game messes with your head more and more the further into the game you get and it's all explained at the end of the game which has to be one of the best endings in gaming history.

As you might understand I love the story and I think most people will love it as much as I do.

When it comes to gameplay it unfortunately gets repetetive far too fast, mainly beacouse you're limited to 2 weapons at a time and secondly beacouse every enemy encounter is almost the same and there is very little time between every enemy encounter.
But it is good 'till it gets repetetive and when it does it's still ok.

The upgrade system is changed from the previous games. there is no longer ADAM but instead there are infusions which improves your shield, health or salt.
Then we have the gear... the gear seems worthless exept for like 3 pieces of it!
The only gear I found usefull was a piece that made enemies drop ammo 40% of the time, one that gave me health if I killed an enemy while low on health and finally one that gave me more damage while aiming down sight which improved quickscoping.
Yes... you can quickscope in Bioshock Infinite!

Bioshock Infinites  graphics are absolutely stunning! They look really modern which always improves the experience.

Overall this is a great game that everybody should play.

Zum dritten und letzten mal nimmt die Bioshock Serie den Spieler in ein wundervoll gestaltetes, nach Utopie riechend und nach verrottetem Kadaver schmeckendes Paralleluniversum. Dass die Utopie nicht lange hält ist jedesmal klar. Zu groß die Versprechungen von Comstock und Ryan, zu eigensinnig die zwei Schöpfer der beiden Städte. Dem Spieler ist von Anfang an klar, dass diese Utopie nicht lange halten wird, und dass man selbst eine Art Messias im Spiel darstellt. (Dies gilt vor allem für Teil 1 & Teil 3, der zweite Teil ist spielerisch und für den Gesamtzusammenhang nicht gerade wichtig)
Spielerisch wird nicht unbedingt viel neues geboten, die Gefechte machen weiterhin Spaß, der Einsatz der Vigors in Kombination mit den Waffen erinnert immernoch an Rollenspiele, verliert aber nicht an Reiz. Neu jedoch sind Gefechte bei denen man sich mit der "Sky-Hook"-Klaue an Rails festhält und während des Slidens Gegnerhorden erledigt oder per Sturzangriff "platt" macht. Es bleibt zwischen den Kämpfen aber viel Zeit sich das wunderschön gestaltete Columbia anzuschauen und in seine Geschichte und den Verfall einzudringen. Begleitet wird man von Elizabeth, die selbst nicht kämpft, dafür "Tears" öffnen kann, und wie in Bioshock 1 die Little Sisters einen übermächtigen Beschützer an der Backe hat.
Der interessanteste Teil am Spiel sind nicht die Kämpfe, es ist vielmehr die Geschichte und vor allem das Ende, bei dem sich eine im Computerspiel in dieser Form noch nie dagewesene Selbstreflexivität zeigt. Am Schluss wird nicht nur die Geschichte der Bioshock Trilogie episch beendet, sondern es wird auch auf einzigartige Weise über das Spiel selbst und weiterhin alle Spiele die den Spieler in ein eigenes Universum nehmen philosophiert. Sobald man durch den Leuchtturm geht, und auch schon das zum Leuchtturm gehen selbst, hat man keine Wahl als den Pfad des Spiels zu folgen, auch wenn man mal links oder rechts geht, am Ende ist die Geschichte für alle gleich. Damit ist Bioshock Infinite eines der ersten Spiele die das Medium Computerspiel als selbstreflexives Kunstwerk benutzen. Auch die rund zehn Stunden Spielzeit vorher offenbaren die Möglichkeiten des Mediums durch die Erkundung der Parallelwelt, für mich jedoch ist dies das erste Spiel, das vollkommen vom realistischen Ansatz hinweggeht und auch im Sinne der Post-Modernen Kunst aus allen Epochen zitiert und etwas ganz neues Schafft.

Anmerkung:
Nach dem Ende von Bioshock Infinite geht es mit 3 DLC's weiter, ein Arcade-artiges mit Kämpfen und Highscores, aber auch zwei die die Geschichte der Trilogie endgültig beenden und den Bioshock Kreis schließen. Spielerisch ist wohl vor allem das zweite interessant, da man einen Schleich-Shooter erhält, man muss sie aber nicht unbedingt spielen, die Geschichte wird etwas runder aber interessanter ist eigentlich das Hauptspiel.

Not everyone was happy with where the developers chose to take this third entry in the almost-legendary Bioshock series, but in my opinion the decisions made were mostly the "right" ones.  MOSTLY.  
 
   Let me just say straight up - and this may well be an opinion subject to change, given that I've played the first two games twice and this but once - that this is probably my "least favourite" of the three games.  This is a purely personal thing:  I am, on the whole, more a fan of "horror" than other fantasy-related genres, and while the first two games were perhaps not strictly of that genre, they certainly leaned more heavily toward it than this latest instalment does.  

   Which brings us to the first two significant decisions made during the development of this game. First up, the change of setting from a ruined, claustrophobic underwater city to a city in the clouds rapidly HEADED towards downfall. And secondly, the shifting of the main "enemy" type from insane, physically-deformed mutants (some with the rough equivalent of supernatural powers) to well-armed soldiers and revolutionaries caught in a power-struggle to either defend or bring down the mad "prophet" who founded their would-be utopia.  

   It's obviously a matter of personal taste which of these two "tones" one prefers. But in spite of myself generally favouring the earlier of the two settings, I have to admit that they really COULD NOT have gotten away with a third game set in the city of Rapture.  So all things considered, I'm conceding that they probably made the "right" decision.  It was due time to change things up a little, and they've done so in a way which is equal parts "obvious" (moving from a city under the sea to a city in the clouds) and "inspired" (they really could have just done another POST-apocalyptic scenario, but instead chose to tell an entirely different story...and good for them)!
 
   This said, the actual GAMEPLAY is remarkably similar to the earlier games, with one important exception:  they've replaced a bunch of lovable (if slightly creepy) little girls with a single grown woman, and this is arguably where things differ the most.  Say goodbye to the oddly endearing task of liberating and/or baby-sitting "Little Sisters", and say hello to a sassy, would-be "romantic" interest who's constantly torn between despising our (anti-) hero for his "brute"-like behaviour, and being strangely attracted to him for, well, basically the same reasons (hmmph...women)!  

   Not only does this change the tone of the piece quite significantly - call me a sap and/or misogynist, but I was actually quite moved by all the "take care of the cute little gals" antics of parts 1 and 2 - but in effect also makes this a much more linear experience than the first two games. Our only reason to "backtrack" now is to get more goodies hidden behind doors which our female companion can helpfully pick the locks of, rather than the far more involved task of harvesting "ADAM" required in the first two games.  

   In short, we've lost a bit of tiny bit of strategizing along the way, in favour of a more straight-forwardly arcade-y experience of moving from location to location and killing lots of things and picking up a bunch of stuff.  Again...personal preference will decide for the individual whether this is a good or bad thing.  I myself found it all a bit repetitive and "draggy" towards the end, and found myself mainly using only two of the eight "vigors"/special powers on offer, but y'know...that's just me.  
 
   Whichever way you look at it, this is still a pretty smart, classy game.  It boasts some of the best graphics in video game history (think an ultraviolent "Disney" cartoon, and you're getting warm), and a pretty interesting storyline to boot (though I gotta say, the people who made such a huge fuss over the supposedly "controversial" ending...you people really need to read more, or at the very least stop watching all those fucking Michael Bay and Marvel movies, 'cause it really wasn't THAT much of a mind-blowing revelation at the end).  

   There's every chance I'll even find myself utterly adoring it the second time around, but right now...frankly, I'm a little "spectacular"-ed out.  Which is a way of saying this game isn't exactly anyone's definition of "subtle", so if that's what you're looking for...I dunno, maybe try Gone Home or something instead.  But if it's slam-bang action and jaw-dropping scenery you want, with just a pinch of cleverness and mind-fucking thrown in to lend a little spice, there's not much risk of finding disappointment here. 
 
Verdict: 9/10.

I have mixed feelings when it comes to this game. The gameplay is solid, although quite unrealistic; but this is understandable for Bioshock.

Good things: It was fun, the story was engaging and the world was unique, it gave a nice open-air feel as opposed to underwater.

Bad things: People were too bullet resistant. I think this changes on the easier difficulties, but on the hardest (not 1999 because I hadn't unlocked it) you would be shooting someone from the the Columbia PD 3 or 4 times in the head before they died. The sky hook thing was a nice game mechanic, but I never understood and still don't understand how a spinny metal thing on your arm lets you run and jump 30m through the air and grab onto a hook. Why it doesn't dislocate your arm at the elbow and the shoulder is also a puzzle. When Booker is holding two handed guns, he suddenly doesn't have the massive metal thing on his arm, but when you melee he swings his arm out and there's the sky hook. The front sights and rear sights were way too large on all of the firearms, and realistically you could not shoot accurately with them. The weapons were a little weird, with some of them quite antique for 1912 and others way ahead of the time period. This was explained via the tears though. I've seen the video about how everyone would be throwing up from motion sickness, and I won't elaborate on that. It seems that the only currency in Columbia is the Silver Eagle, which you spend like dollars in the 21st century. All the signs that have fireworks and popcorn at prices like 10c are meaningless unless you have those coins.................you don't. Like all games of this type, there's the ability to carry thousands of coins the size of your palm around in some kind of mega wallet that doesn't make you move like a snail, need I say more? Fink has all of the workers making the manufactured goods, but where does the fresh fruit come from? I see oranges in baskets, and yet I see no floating agricultural area anywhere in game or on the map. There are quite a lot of people in Columbia, but they don't really seem to do much apart from look at the various monuments or talk to each other. There are the shops and businesses, but not much in the way of employment for everyone else. In that time period it was common for the rich to live off inheritance and investments, but it's not like the economy in Columbia could thrive without trade.

Honestly I could go on for a thousand pages and I think I'll leave it there.

One of my most special gaming sessions in a while. This is one of my top 10 games of all times. 

Just like the focus of TV series took an incredible turn for STORY the last 10 years, computer games in 2014 is only as good as its STORY. Bioshock Infinite has an AMAZING STORY. 

The game is not nearly perfect in most other ways, but for everyone extremely tired of the "fight, fight, fight, reward, fight, fight"-mechanism of most games these days, the STORY of Bioshock Infinite will be extremely pleasing. The fighting sessions are easy, and won't take more time than what they should in any game to advance the story and the characters.

While I'm at it, let me recommend the Bioshock 1 and 2 games at the same time. They are VERY different, but still some of the gloominess and is retained throughout the series.

(spoiler alert, stop reading if you don't want to know)

The biggest problem I have with this game, is how the story actually manages to destroy the whole Bioshock Universe. The scriptwriters probably felt it would give "infinite possibilities" but the ending actually destroys all my feelings for the Bioshock Universe, and I'd rather not visit it again. TREMENDOUS loss. But at the same time the 3 Bioshock games will forever stand tall as a ginormous gaming trilogy, however without any further prequels or sequels - pretty much like the Lord of the Rings movies - the trilogy is "it". There's no more, and can never be. The story ends here.

But MAN what an amazing journey until that point.

Одна из лучших игр, в которые я играл. Она настолько хороша, что может сравниться с моей любимой трилогией [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/worganomor/recommended/24980/]Mass Effect[/url].

Изначально, еще до того как начать играть, я почитал много восторженных отзывов, но относился к игре с некоторой долей скептицизма. Однако, после того как я погрузился в этот мир, у меня не было ни тени сомнения в том, что Инфинит поразит меня до глубины души.

Сюжет этой игры невероятно динамичен и сложен, с одной стороны он развивается постепенно и создает иллюзию предсказуемости, но резкие развороты в самые неожиданные моменты напрочь разрушают это иллюзию. Сюжетная линия мощная и драматичная одновременно, а концовка настолько сложна и неожиданна, что вызывает чувство радости, горести и смятения одновременно.

Отдельно хочется отметить проработку персонажей в целом и Элизабет в частности. Скажу честно, большую часть игры я провел за наблюдениями, происходящими с Лиз, по мере совершения сюжетных событий. Девочка из башни попала в реальный мир, полный жестокости и страданий, даже в такой утопии как Колумбия, и все события, происходящие с вами, оставляют свой след на ней. Легко можно заметить как рушатся ее представления и как ей приходится принимать новые условия, в которых она оказалась. Характер Элизабет создан настолько качественно, что ей не возможно не сопереживать.

Графическая составляющая так же на высоте, как и дизайн уровней. Единственный минус - текстуры начинают прорисовываться когда подходишь к ним, а на расстоянии они низкого качества. Такой же проблемой страдал и второй Байошок, а вот в первом все было нормально. Но это не так страшно и привыкаешь за 10 минут.

Подводя итог, можно сказать: BioShock Infinite определенно одна из лучших игр, когда-либо созданных. С мощным сюжетом, интересным геймплеем, атмосферным саундреком, харизматичными персонажами и отличной графикой. Что еще для счастья надо? Разве что вторую часть, ведь история еще не окончилась.

Quite possibly one of the greatest stories ever written in videogame history. Bioshock Infinite might be overrated in the sense that it is widely considered by a newer generation of gamers the best game of all time which it is not, but it is definitely one of THE best games of all time.

Years after the launch of the 1st game in the series, one of the great geniouses of gaming Ken Levine is back to yet again tell us a great story and at the same time deliver with a great action FPS. The animations are superb and the graphic design is subtle yet impressive at the same time. The balance between different vigors and weapons, create a good gameplay and many different tactics to approach the field of combat. The world of the game is rich, and full of detail in most characters and environments, there's always something new to see each time you play it.

The only thing Bioshock Infinite would need to even better, was if it were less Linear and with more variety in therms of activities within the game. Could've benefited from a more open roam world and more than just shoot and hack your way through waves of enemies, but for what it is, it is superb.

Hate it or love it, it is undoubtedly one of the best games of the last decade.

Bioshock infinite was a very big surprise, I picked it up for the summersale in july and I feel that I actually should have payed more for it. It's just a joy to see this story evolve but I really recommend to pay attention while playing or else you will have a hard time understanding this wonderfull story. 

The gameplay itself was fun, you had your primary weapons (ranging from pistols to rocketlaunchers and you can hold 2 of them) and you also have these "vigors", they are abilities that your character can do, throw fire, electrify people and so on... 

In the end I really recommend this game and would give it a 9/10 for graphics 8.5 for the gameplay and a 10/10 for story.

Hope that is good enough.  The reason why I consider this game worse than the previous two is because it only has one ending, and the plot just goes horribly sideways towards the end of the story.  The voice acting is great, but the increasingly absurd and floundering plot really hurts the game.  The time travel component is handled even worse than Star Trek plots usually do, which is really saying something.  Basically, this game shows great execution and is fun to play, but really suffers from bad writing and an unsatisfying ending.  Your choices in the other Bioshock games have an effect on the ending - in Bioshock Infinite almost nothing you do matters.

Bioshock Infinite has been in my game library since the Christmas sale i want to say maybe fall sale of 2013. Bought it as a combo pack with all three games.  Friend has been raving about the series for years to me. I play the first and am blown away by the story.  Start the second one and couldn't even get past an an hour into and am thinking total garbage.  So the third installment I put on hold for quite awhile.  Finally get a wild hair to sit down and play it.  It is a very graphical stunning game.  I'm a little at a lose on written this review because it's a good game possible a great one with one thing I'm not 100% sold on the story.  The story is good but it was completely rushed it starts out slow like the first one that's fine getting your bearings and the lay of the land.  But then you hit the action and it's done quicker then a plate of oreos' at a weight watchers meeting.    It leaves you wanting more or it does in my opinion.  A person could easily finish this game in ten hours just rushing it not exploring or all that jazz.  I would feel even more cheap, dirty, and used like a five dollar hooker if I had paid full price for the game.  I did not so the feeling passed pretty quickly think I picked up all three and the season pass for idk around $20.  The story itself is good but you wish it had a little more detail to it.  All in all a good game don't let this review discourage your from purchasing it.  And the ending linking up to the Bioshock original wasn't even needed.  Love how they did just not fundamental to the story.  I would rate this game a 7.5 maybe an 8 but more towards the 7.5 mark.   Graphics superbly done. Story I liked it but didn't love it.  All in all if your a fan of the first skip the second and purchase this one.  If your new to series doesn't matter the order you play them just skip the second and your golden.  This game should definitaly be on your wishlist at the very least.
